U.S. Treasury's Bessent calls out crypto 'nihilists' resisting market structure bill

รัฐมนตรีคลังสหรัฐฯ สก็อตต์ เบสเซนต์ (Scott Bessent) วิจารณ์อย่างหนักแน่นกลุ่มผู้นำในอุตสาหกรรมคริปโทที่ต่อต้านร่างกฎหมายโครงสร้างตลาดสินทรัพย์ดิจิทัล โดยประณามพวกเขาว่าเป็น "กลุ่มไนฮิลิสต์" ที่ต้องการอยู่ไร้กฎระเบียบ ในการไต่สวนต่อหน้าคณะกรรมการการธนาคารวุฒิสภา เบสเซนต์ยืนยันว่าการผ่านกฎหมาย Digital Asset Market Clarity Act เป็นสิ่งสำคัญที่อุตสาหกรรมจำเป็นต้องได้รับเพื่อก้าวหน้าในสหรัฐฯ และพูดตรงไปตรงมาว่าหากใครไม่ต้องการกฎระเบียบที่เข้มแข็ง ควรย้ายไปอยู่ที่เอลซัลวาดอร์ เบสเซนต์ได้รับการสนับสนุนจากวุฒิสมาชิก Mark Warner จากพรรคเดโมแครต ผู้ซึ่งมีความกังวลในจุดเดียวกันเกี่ยวกับความมั่นคงของชาติและภัยคุกคามทางการเงินในภาคส่วนของ Decentralized Finance (DeFi) แม้ว่าผู้นำอุตสาหกรรมอย่าง CEO ของ Coinbase จะถอนการสนับสนุนเนื่องจากปัญหาเรื่อง Stablecoin yield และคำนิยามสินทรัพย์ แต่นักกฎหมายหลายคนยังคงมั่นใจว่าจะสามารถบรรลุข้อตกลงร่วมกันระหว่างพรรคต่างๆ ได้ในปีนี้

EN

U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent strongly criticized crypto industry insiders resisting the proposed digital assets market structure bill, labeling them as "nihilists" who prefer no regulation. During a Senate Banking Committee hearing, Bessent argued that passing the Digital Asset Market Clarity Act is essential for the industry to proceed in the U.S., bluntly suggesting that those who oppose strong regulation should "move to El Salvador." Bessent found an unlikely ally in Democratic Senator Mark Warner, who shares concerns about national security risks and illicit finance within Decentralized Finance (DeFi). While industry figures like Coinbase CEO Brian Armstrong have withdrawn support due to issues regarding stablecoin yield rewards and securities definitions, lawmakers like Senator Angela Alsobrooks remain optimistic that a bipartisan compromise can be reached this year.

Key Points

  • U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent called resistant crypto participants "nihilists" and suggested they move to El Salvador if they oppose regulation.
  • Bessent emphasized that passing the Digital Asset Market Clarity Act is crucial for the industry's advancement in the U.S.
  • Senator Mark Warner is focused on addressing national security gaps and illicit finance risks within Decentralized Finance (DeFi).
  • Industry figures, including Coinbase's CEO, have criticized the bill over stablecoin yield rewards and securities definitions.
  • Bessent stated that U.S.-regulated private stablecoins are a superior option compared to Central Bank Digital Currencies (CBDCs).

Article

Treasury Secretary Bessent said market participants who don't want strong regulation should "move to El Salvador." Updated Feb 5, 2026, 7:47 p.m. Published Feb 5, 2026, 5:40 p.m. U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent fired warning shots at crypto insiders who are pushing back in the negotiations over a digital assets market structure bill in the Senate — briefly aligning with Democratic Senator Mark Warner in expressing frustration during a hearing on Thursday . "There seems to be a nihilist group in the industry who prefers no regulation over this very good regulation," Bessent said in testimony before the Senate Banking Committee. STORY CONTINUES BELOW "Amen, brother," said Virginia Senator Warner, one of the key Democratic negotiators on the bill. "So weigh in." "I do," Bessent responded. "Early and often." A number of crypto industry participants, including Coinbase CEO Brian Armstrong , have been critical of provisions in the bill, pointing to concerns around how it addresses decentralized finance regulation, stablecoin yield rewards and the way it defines tokens as securities. Armstrong's withdrawal of support for a version of the legislation moving through the Senate Banking Committee last month had been consequential. Warner said in the hearing that a further meeting is expected on the regulatory effort within the next few days, and he suggested Bessent was set to be invited. In those ongoing talks, Warner has been an outspoken voice on crypto's illicit finance threats , leading much of that discussion in the legislative negotiations. "I feel like I'm in crypto hell," Warner said, eliciting some laughs in the hearing room. "We are working our tail off." He said other technical points in the bill can be resolved, but he suggested addressing "some of the gaps" related to national security and decentralized finance (DeFi) remains his focus. "We'll deal with yields and rewards; we'll deal with a host of other issues; but these national security issues around DeFi are real, and we need to not create a set of rules that leaves huge exemptions and, candidly, takes away some of the prosecutorial powers that exist today," Warner said. Bessent, who didn't call out any resistant crypto industry representatives by name, went on to underline the importance of passing the Digital Asset Market Clarity Act in the Senate. The bill has struggled to maintain momentum as lobbyists from crypto and banking have clashed with each other over the question of stablecoin yield and lawmakers from the parties can't find agreement on certain other provisions. The Treasury secretary argued the industry can't advance in the U.S. unless the bill passes. "It's impossible to proceed without it," he said. "We have to get this Clarity Act across the finish line. And any market participants who don't want it should move to El Salvador." Bessent said that he thinks the earlier GENIUS Act to regulate U.S. stablecoin issuers struck a good balance that can eventually be repeated in the Clarity Act. "There seem to be people who want to live in the US, but not have rules for this important industry, and we've got to bring safe, sound and smart practices and the oversight of the U.S. government, but also allow for the freedom that is crypto," Bessent said, adding that as both parties continue to work on the Clarity Act, it can get "across the line this year." Senator Angela Alsobrooks, a Democratic lawmaker who has worked on a compromise on stablecoin yield in the market structure bill, predicted at the hearing that the legislation will reach a bipartisan compromise. "I feel really good that we're going to get a bipartsan compromise that protects innovation and our community banks," she said. Also at Thursday's hearing, Senator Cynthia Lummis, the Republican head of the panel's crypto subcommittee, asked Bessent whether China was pursuing a digital assets system meant to rival U.S. financial leadership. "We don't know that for sure," he answered. "There are lots of rumors of Chinese digital assets that may be backed by something other than the RMB [China's yuan], perhaps gold base." He said he "would not be surprised" if China sought to compete. In a similar vein, when asked about central bank digital currencies (CBDCs), such as the government-tied tokens pursued in China and Europe, he said that U.S.-regulated private stablecoins will be a superior option for global users.
